ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef

Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Degraff
Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef
Dana Graef

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Very engaging class, excellent readings and atmosphere for discussion.

The TA was always available and very helpful. She played a much more involved role than my TAs in other classes. I did not love the format of the class - we had 1/2 lecture, 1/2 discussion. I would have liked for the two to be more integrated.
The topics covered in the course were enlightening and very necessary for anybody interested in development.
The course would have greatly benefited from an introduction to social science and a conclusion. The last class should not be more of the same but give closure. I did not feel it did that.
Question 9: This course could benefit from some field work/trips, or having speakers come in.
This course was for me the best class i have taken. As a development worker, it provided me insights developmental interventions and its impact. The class was thought provoking and an eye opener.
The professor and the discussion
The student discussions and getting to debate, interact, ask questions, and listen to experiences. I also liked when the instructor brought goodies to class!

The final paper was a great way to incorporate a lot of what we learned. The best part of the class was being able to incorporate this new knowledge into an area of our personal interest. This flexibility was great.
The way its structured is extremely conducive to learning.
The readings and the lectures but not the discussion.
The materials used for the course gave a different perspective on the topics covered.

The readings were wonderfully well-chosen. Each week's readings complemented their counterparts, and reinforced and expanded on earlier themes. The weekly thesis sentence assignment ensured close reading a shared starting point for discussion.

The class allows people to articulate ideas about development and conservation as well as structure their arguments for or against it. Also, the reading expose student to what is being read about development and conservation.
The readings. Many of them were very informative. The class discussions and lectures were also great.
The interaction with students
The lecture/discussion format of class kept the course interesting. I particularly enjoyed that the discussions were student-led and tended to be tailored to personal interests of the students.
Our class discussions. We had a very broad and diverse class which made for very interesting class discussions.
The reading materials. Though i struggled with some of the reading materials, it was very engaging and thought provoking.

Reading different case analysis from diverse parts of the world.Redirecting my view and standpoint on the underlying aspects of development and conservation initiatives. This course has provided me with awareness knowledge on how to look into my own biases and perspectives on development and conservation.I also enjoyed the in-class discussions on the weekly readings.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Do not read out loud who wrote amazing sentences. It is uncomfortable for both those who did well and those who didn't. If you want us to have an understanding of good thesis sentences, email them to the course without the author's name.
I did not find the thesis sentences to be that helpful, except for when it came to writing the final paper.
This class is perfect. Nothing needs improvement.

I thought that the instructor could perhaps have spent a bit more time lecturing about the readings and also in greater detail.I also think that encouraging more critique and critical analysis of the readings during class discussion would also be useful to stimulate more independent thinking about the ideas presented through the readings.
The discussion.
It would help to improve the way students receive feedback on assignments.
A closer commitment to the content of the readings during class discussion. We had a tendency to stray rather far.

At points during the semester, it was very repetitive. The readings had the same tone and the same thing with the discussion in class. This made student loose interest in the class and get tired. Also, the methodology to conduct discussions needs to be evaluated because the current set up leads to only a few people talking. Some people never spoke.

The readings. There wasn't enough time to read and then digest the material. I also think there was a bit of a break down in communication between the instructor and the T.A. I have talked to them both about different topics, to get different responses on information that should have been the same, or similar.
Everything about the course is balanced.

I recommend that the course starts with a general explanation of the social sciences and the major actors/concepts related to the analysis the class will partake throughout the semester. This first class will serve as an important guide/tool for the analysis and evaluations undertaken within class discussions.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: great
Both the instructor and TA were very available and very helpful. They listened, gave advice, were clear, and sometimes even pointed me towards specific articles/authors I should read. Wonderful.
Excellent. Dana was always accommodating and was a huge help!
The instructor and the TA were both amazing, always available for help.
Availability and quality of help received from the instructor and TA was excellent.
They were both really great at helping me with my issues and thoughts in the class.
I have contacted both the instructor and the TA, and both of them were readily available and helpful.
Both the professor and TA were extremely accessible and responsive.
Excellent
Both instructor and TA availability were great.
Very very available. TA and the instructor were very approachable and very very helpful, as well as encouraging.

The TA was wonderful! She was always available and led great pre-discussion meetings prior to class. The instructor was also available to guide students on their term paper and discuss concepts presented in class.
Help was always available.
Both the instructor and TA were always available each week.
The availability and quality of help from both Prof. Carpenter and Dana Graef were excellent, especially in the development of the final class project.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: part of my social ecology education

I am concerned with social ecology, and I think everyone with similar interests should take this course. It teaches you so much about how humans relate to nature, the balance of power across the globe, and different discourses.

This course gave me a different perspective in examining conservation and development projects. I think the social implications of these projects are underestimated and Carol brought a lot of perspective that was refreshing.
It's not something I specifically sought out but I took it because it's a bin requirement and it's one of the best classes I've taken at FES because it helps me to think in a much broader picture.
A course that accounts for the assumptions we aspiring environmental professions make in our pursuits. Brings the human element lacking in so many other courses.
It is a great course if you are interested in doing policy analysis and policy design because it exposes to criticism of development and conservation policies and agendas.
This course gave me a great understanding of how communities and individuals are impacted by conservation and development practices of environmental organizations.
It gives me a fresh perspective

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: to learn more about anthropological theory of conservation and development
I took the course to understand more about the social issues underlying development projects and how to address them in project implementation.
I took this course because it puts everything we do as environmental scientists into a very necessary social context.
I took it primarily to fulfill one of my bin requirements, but also because I have an interest in humanity's motivation behind conservation.
Bin requirement.
Bin requirement
I intend to focus on development studies, and this course offered the chance to approach this topic from a different and very relevant perspective.
I hoped an intellectual engagement with the issues would help to me overcome the nearly paralyzing guilt I felt when considering intervention in communities not my own.
I have an interest in understanding the impacts of development and conservation policies on people, as well as their effectiveness.
To gain a better understanding of the social science behind conservation and development.

Having little background in social science but interested in international development, I was drawn to this course in order to gain an anthropological perspective on the conservation and development work I hope to do in the future.

As a natural resource practitioner, I understand that the social sciences is an important complement to the policy and science load that enviromental managers work with. Understanding the social component of development and environmental initiatives is of utmost importance.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: yes

Yes, under the disclaimer that Carol gave in the beginning of the class, which was that she would not teach practice, but rather analysis of problems in practice. She noted this at the beginning, so I knew that while I wanted advice for practice, the class would not be geared toward that.
It exceeded my expectations
Far exceeded. I was really not interested in the course to begin with but it has been one of my favorite courses.
Yes!
Absolutely. Academically and emotionally tough, but tremendously supportive.
Yes and No. As mentioned earlier, many times it was repetitive.
Yes, this course exceeded my expectations.
It surpassed my expectations!
Yes.
Yes, the class more than lived up to my expectation. It was excellent.
The course lived up to my expectations.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes
yes.
I got from it more than I expected. I thought I would be introduced to social theories, but this class gave me a framework for analyzing the world around me.
More than expected. I didn't know I could think like this and call it school.
Yes
In some cases, I got out more than I expected.
Absolutely.
Yes and No. I wish there would have been a more explicit discussion regarding the added value of social science to development and conservation.
Yes. Carol did a great job of pushing me and challenging me in my understanding of the concepts in the readings, and in my writing.
Yes I did
Yes.
Yes.
I got more than I expected. As I mentioned before, this course has provided me with awareness knowledge on how to look into my own biases and perspectives on development and conservation.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I thought participating in group work helped me understand the readings better.
groups of 4 were too large to lead discussions with.

The main advantage is that you get different perspectives on the issues discussed, so the breath and depth of the outcome improves greatly.The disadvantage is that you have to adapt to other people's work style, although that is a very necessary skill to develop!
Twice in the semester, we split into small groups to lead the class discussion. A nice opportunity to learn the particular interests of my classmates. A low-stress, friendly group undertaking.
The work group went well.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Keep up with the readings and engage in discussions, ask questions.

Take the time to read articles carefully. I know it's time consuming, but it will be helpful for the paper later on. Spend a bit more time on the articles you know for sure will relate to your paper topic.

The class requires a lot of reading and the thesis sentences can be quite onerous on a weekly basis. Anticipate the long paper at the end of the semester and plan for it accordingly starting early in the semester.
Have an open mind.
Be open minded and try to engage with discussions as much as possible.

Expect to spend a fair bit of time outside of class (and your readings) questioning your right/ability to do good. Take the readings seriously (and with only three a week, you actually have time to do them justice), and don't ignore the recommended readings. Some are golden.

Be prepared for a heave course load and repetitive discussions. However, for people that have never been exposed to social sciences, i think they would benefit greatly from being exposed to this material.
Your thinking will be challenged. Keep an open mind during both lectures and discussions.
Mastering the thesis sentence summary of papers is challenging but a very useful technique.
Start your term paper early!
The reading materials for the course is very intriguing, thought provinking and engaging. The class discussions were excellent and interesting.

I recommend taking this course, as I understand that the social sciences is an important complement to the policy and science load that environmental managers work with.Understanding the social component of development and environmental initiatives is of utmost importance. This course will facilitate readings and discussions that will expand your awareness and critical analysis of development and conservation.
